posts.name: Vicky
posts.cooked:
For some reason our can bus conntections to our spark max have loss some of the wire loops. We assume this was what was causing issues with our sparks maxs and how they were not reciving any signals. Is this assumption correct? And if so could someond explain the issue it was causing. Also our can wires keep getting cut, is there any solution to this, or anyway to prevent or help avoid this? 20230228_181240 1920×3413 349 KB

20230228_181240 1920×3413 349 KB

20230228_181240 1920×3413 349 KB
The one on the right doesn’t have the same redundancy as the one on the left. I would recommend replacing it with a new CAN cable.

posts.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
posts.cooked: Pulling out the loop wire also makes the other wire termination iffy if not pulled out.
posts.display_username: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: So V1 of these connectors did not have the extra wire loops, did yours get pulled out or these older connectors? The point of that extra loop is so that if your connector comes unplugged from the Spark you do not lose the whole can bus. For durability I recommend you replace this with a new cable assembly. Now if this extra loop just got pulled out and if your “can wires keep getting cut”, I think we need a bigger picture of how your electronics are mounted and of your wiring job as these are bigger issues that should be resolved.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Vicky
posts.cooked: I am pretty sure that the loops got pulled out somehow, but I did have another team mate messing around with the Can wires, so they could have simply switched some connections for the older versions by mistake. We have already replaced the Can wires of the sparks. As for the can bus wires getting cut, after looking over the all the can connections its seems that the wires are getting cut from the plastic that protects where some Can wires connect to others. The little white plastic. After looking at how my teammates were handling what are electrical is mounded on I think that some of my teammates were just being a little too rough causing some wires to be tugged to the point that they got ripped out. I can try to take a photo of the electrical set up tomorrow. I do think it was just a design fault on my part with the set up.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
V19:

After looking at how my teammates were handling what are electrical is mounded on I think that some of my teammates were just being a little too rough causing some wires to be tugged to the point that they got ripped out.

Our electrical team was by invitation only. We watched how they did their work when being trained to drill holes and cut materials and invited the ones who were obviously careful, meticulous and paid attention when being trained. We have not had anywhere as many electrical problems as on other teams I have been on and we just had to train them just once.
